description:
Pristipomoides typus, commonly known as the Oriental snapper or golden snapper, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Lutjanidae (snappers). It is primarily found in the Indo-Pacific region, inhabiting tropical and subtropical waters.

Morphologically, Pristipomoides typus is characterized by a moderately elongated, slightly compressed body shape. It has a large, protruding mouth with a prominent lower jaw and small, conical teeth. The dorsal fin is continuous, with 10 spines and 11 soft rays, while the anal fin has 3 spines and 8 soft rays. The scales are small and ctenoid (rough to the touch), covering the body and the head. The coloration of the fish is typically golden-yellow or orange-red, with a silvery-white underside.

Ecologically, Pristipomoides typus is a demersal species, typically found in coral reef habitats, rocky areas, and deep-water environments at depths ranging from 20 to 400 meters. It is an opportunistic predator, feeding on a variety of small fishes, crustaceans, and mollusks. The species is of significant commercial and recreational importance, being a popular target for fisheries in many regions of its distribution.
